newsitem.title: USA: Cattlemen criticize USDA's proposed EQIP rule.
newsitem.headline: Cattlemen criticize USDA's proposed EQIP rule.

text.p: National Cattlemen's Beef Association Thursday criticized USDA's proposed rule for the Environmental Quality Incentive Program saying it created "more burdens than incentives."

"NCBA continues to support the premise of the EQIP but feels the proposed rule creates more burdens than incentives for producers and raises more questions and uncertainties than it resolves," said Jim Little, chairman of the trade group's Property Rights and Environmental Management Committee.

USDA needs to clarify at what point an EQIP contract is formed and if it can be modified, what standards will be used to determine environmental protection and cost-effectiveness, and who has access to participants' property, NCBA said in a statement. It said it has supplied written comments to USDA.

In October, USDA unveiled rules for the $1.3 billion program, which would provide cost-share money and expert advice to crop and livestock farmers who want to make environmental and conservation improvements. Half the money is for livestock farmers. EQIP was created as part of the 1996 farm policy law.
